comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Likely to be the Anniversary Day Regatta 26/1/1884.

Can anyone identify the Manly paddle steamer, full of folk dressed up for a Grand Day Out ?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Fear not! We have passed this photo to our friendly ferry consultant & will post the results post haste :) Might help clear up the other details.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/65669741@N08] Thank you!

See another FAIRLIGHT photo by Mr Hall for comments and further links -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8163057702/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: She seems to be travelling 'backwards' here, the bridge behind the funnel, blocking the view. That's what caused the accident in 1882 - www.ferriesofsydney.com/fairlight.html

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65669741@N08] Interesting! Another suggestion re the identity of this ferry was PS NARRABEEN, but it wasn't launched until 1886 - so I'd say our ferry is FAIRLIGHT! Thanks folks.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 65669741@N08
comment._content: If she's heading to Manly then she's aligned correctly - traditionally all Manly ferries travel bow first to Manly, stern first to Sydney.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65669741@N08] Thanks - good to know. We have updated our records accordingly :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I just discovered that the Admiralty House second floor (see notes) was added in 1891-2,  not 1885 (Wikipedia article is misleading).  This might throw out the dating of these ORIENT photos - as far as I can tell, the ORIENT was the flagship at the 1884 Anniversary Regatta only.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] No stone unturned Beachcomber! Thanks for the update :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
